reviewText:
I played the demo for Blades of Time, and I thought it was pretty good, so I bought it in a bundle and bought this with a 90% coupon I got for free.  To be honest, my expectations were low--X-Blades has a pretty poor reputation from what I've read, so it couldn't really go anywhere but up.  It took me nine hours to beat the game though I could've cut it down if I wasn't stuck in one portion.

X-Blades is the story of a young woman in a skimpy outfit destroying statues and vases while slaughtering scores of monsters and critters.  I guess I'd classify it as a beat-em-up of sorts, the kind where the game will seal off an exit and you have to deplete a health bar on the bottom of the screen with enough monster death to continue.  Or maybe you have to find these monster generators and destroy all of them AND kill all of the monsters in the area to continue.  Combat is fairly simple, as you attack with your gunblades with slashes or shooting at distant enemies.  There's a Rage meter that rises with damage dealt and taken, which falls with time or when casting spells, as it's kinda like an MP bar in a way.  You gain Souls from enemies you butcher and the things you destroy, which you spend on learning new spells or getting in a quick anytime heal or Rage boost.

Battles are largely repetitive barring the boss battles.  You usually have enemies spawn in over a series of waves and you destroy them, or do the same with the monster generators, and then you get a Level Complete and you're free to explore the stages for artifact pieces to power up your attacks or other goodies.  All while staring at your character's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•...I'm sorry, where was I?  There really aren't any puzzles to solve again barring some of the boss fights, and you typically get a bestiary update that tells you pretty much how to beat the foe.  This is the first game I've played where the bestiary updates BEFORE you kill something, but it's a handy hint system kinda thing.

For things the game did right...there's a pretty big variety of spells to spend your Souls on.  Granted there aren't many effects, but they are at least somewhat different.  Earthquake can't hit foes in the air, Ray of Light works best on darkness-aligned creatures, and Lightning Range is a kickass chain lightning spell.  There are only four quickslots for spells but you can call up the menu and cast a spell there if you have enough Rage, to make use of a few combos or to use something you don't have bound.  The music is a bit repetitive, being pretty heavy on the rock side during battles, but it kinda grew on me to be honest.  Even the title theme sounded bad...at first.  It's tolerable now, though I don't have to listen to it very much.  And the manual is written entirely in-character, which I realize is corny as hell but I kinda liked it.  There's also a results screen at the end of each stage so you can at least see if you missed any artifact pieces or are going for 100% completeness or something.  And you can go right back to the previous stage if you want, but no stage-select feature here, unfortunately.

As for what I didn't like, some of the controls kinda bothered me.  There was a section I was stuck on that required crossing a chasm or fall to my death, and more than a few times did I accidentally dodge-roll right off a ledge when I meant to jump.  Dying in this game means you start the stage all over.  Did you get a Level Complete and die?  Too bad, start all over!  And this happened to me a few times.  Thankfully that section was optional and this game has no platforming sections like that anywhere else...and you get to keep all of the Souls you had already, so that's some consolation.  Another thing was that the battles were rarely fun and felt like grinding more than anything.  Even when you knew how to kill something, some things just took forever to die, and I hate attrition wars like that.  I did kinda like the game, but at no point did I really tell myself, boy

While not being a great game, it isn‚Äôt a complete waste, nor as bad as people make it out to be.

The bad:
-A completely boring, badly written story, that is completely throwaway, but thankfully doesn‚Äôt hinder you too often or too much.
-Some enemies can be annoying beyond belief, mostly the flying ones and enemies you need to shoot with a special power.
-A lot of throwaway attacks.
-Repetitive. Slashing and shooting enemies from start to finish.
-Below average boss fights that aren‚Äôt always explained well.

The good:
-Gameplay is decently fun, and it feels relatively good.
-Graphics aren‚Äôt overly high-fidelity, but they still have a nice cartoonish look for them and are appealing to the eyes.
-And yes, the main protagonist‚Äôs looks will probably carry this game for a lot of people.

So taking everything in account, the game is nowhere as bad as people often make it out to be. Is it repetitive? Yes, very. Does it have huge mechanical faults? Yes, and you will notice them immediately if you have played any better games of this type. But if you just want a mediocre hack-and-slash with little variety and can ignore some faults and the absence of a proper story, the gameplay and its protagonist (as well as her behind) might be enough to keep you invested and entertained. If you can‚Äôt overlook some of those bigger faults, and solid gameplay and aesthetics aren‚Äôt enough to convince you to spend money on it, you might want to give it a pass. Otherwise, this is a solid little time-sinker for fans of the genre which I recommend buying at any sale.

reviewText:
X-Blades greatest flaw is its redundancy. Enemies, environments and actions will all be extremely familiar territory by the end of the adventure. This isn't helped by the fact that the first portion of X-Blades is spent working your way through arenas in the light of day, then turning around working your way back through those arenas in the evening. It's a serious copout on the part of the developers to not create new architecture and instead relight the same areas. A copout that should not go unnoticed.

What's Good:

- The game offers a nice challenge
- Does a great job at encourging a variety of approaches in battle
- Plenty of upgrades to purchase
- Rewarding collectibles
- Good variety gunplay
- The heavy role magic plays in combat

What's Not-So-Good:

- Battles can be repetitive
- Lack of variety in music
- Uneven difficulty in boss battles (ridiculously easy final boss)
- A few visual errors

What's Bad:

- Overly sensitive movement controls - ^ Unresponsive aerial movements
- Very poor storytelling
- ZERO character development
- Pointless levels
- Penatlizing players for buying life refills with very little alternatives
- Lack of variety in sword combo

In all, there are certain aspects of X-blades that are well developed while there are many others that are not. Depending on your level of tolerance, it can be a decent experience.

reviewText:
Alright.

When I started writing more reviews, I told myself that I should do so after finishing the game. But this here. This game. I... can't wait until I've finished this mess before I write down what exactly I think of X-Blades.

You see, the game suffers from three big R's. Repetition, Recycling, and Redundancy. How so?


Redundancy

For a start, you'll be spammed - SPAMMED, I tell you - with the same enemy type in one of the mind-numbingly short levels for minutes. You better have a durable thumb (or forefinger, depending on wether you play this with a controller or keyboard and mouse), because you'll have to spam back attacks to control those monster hordes. And it's not really entertaining at all. This will go on for every single level. Even the boss battles. You'll be swarmed by mobs.


Repetition

It's not bad enough that the level design is already redundant with the endless monster hordes. Oh no, it gets worse. Because every single level will be the same. Bit of running around, bit of smashing things, button mashing, next level. Rinse and repeat. Rinse and repeat. I last for about 2 or so levels per sitting. I just can't do much more because it's so incredibly badly made.


Recycling

Oh dear. They did not. - Hell yes, they did.
See, it's not bad to use a level again at a later point in time, in maybe slightly altered form, to give the game a nice little looping back. But X-Blades takes it to a sadly very, very lazy extreme. See... you go through the whole dungeon twice. At day and at night. The exact. Same. Rooms. And you do the exact. Same. Thing. Again.


For a game which claims to be of the Hack and Slash genre, X-Blades does a terrible job at introducing something which makes it stand out in the genre. The claims of the reviews that X-Blades is anywhere near as good as DMC is preposterous, even ridiculous. You better check out Metacritic first, and maybe a gameplay video on Youtube. Also, you should probably search for something superior to this.

Even if the game is a bit over 5 years old, this is no excuse at being so utterly terrible. 2009 brought us Overlord II, Dragon Age Origins, and Batman Arkham Asylum.

Think about this.

THINK ABOUT IT.

And keep your hands away from X-Blades.



Oh, in a slightly belated addition: I didn't talk about the gameplay, story, and any of that, did I now? Well. If any of it had been good, I miiiight have forgiven the triple-R offense of the game. But sadly, nothing noteworthy of a story to be found here.

The gameplay and controls feel stiff and rather ininspired. I played with an X-Box 360 Controller for Windows, and, bad as that is, I sometimes didn't notice the controller had lost power and disconnected from the receiver. It took me several seconds to even bother to check the controller at times, since X-Blades's controls have the tendency to feel a little sticky, at least to me.

Next, I'd like to talk about the music briefly. Sadly, the tracks are repetitive, and the in-game music was much too loud for my taste. I had to reduce it to near silence to be able to enjoy the music even remotely. That being said, it was most of the times highly unfitting for the current mood of the game, or at least what I perceived to actually be the intended mood. A tense moment was completely shot to pieces by much too heavy and fast-paced rock music (double offense for the track being the bad, generic kind), and the rest of the time, the music wasn't really adding anything for me. In fact, it felt more like background noise of the obnoxious kind.

Tiny little excourse to the voice-acting - there actually is some in the game! For some reason, even though I selected English as language, the voice-acting was in German... and... meh. MEH. Sorry, but it really, really destroyed the game even more. The voices didn't fit, they sounded uninspired, and the bickering back and forth between Ayumi and the dark wolf boss thingy was painfully childish and immature. Unnecessary, in other words.

Oh, right, the story. To be honest, since I don't plan on finishing the game (yeah... there's only so much mind-numbing stupidity I can deal with), I have nooo idea what the story is about. And even as I read up on it, it seems like it is all over the place. Something of an artifact, someone being possessed, getting repossessed, un-possessed... whatever. I have no idea. I really don't.

Maybe I should also add something about the character design. Good? Good. Or rather, bad. See, there are sexy heroines in tight, short outfits, and then there's Ayumi. I actually felt horribly uncomfortable with her. She looks much too young to wear little more than straps passing as an excuse for clothes. I don't view her as sexy. She has some adorable about her, and that makes things really awkward really fast. Add to that the uninspired childish bickering mentioned in the voice-acting paragraph of the review, and it gets really, really, REALLY awkward and weird.


So, with that added to the already terribly done R's... nope. Not looking any good here, X-Blades. I'm going to play Alice: Madness Returns next, to have some really good Hack and Slash.

reviewText:
Sometimes I wish I didn't get crap like this in bundles so I wouldn't be tempted to play it. Then I play it anyway and wonder why I didn't listen to myself.

If you're really into button mashing, have I got the game for you. This game is all about slamming on the attack button against fodder enemies (combos are for wimps) until your rage (read: mana) meter is filled up enough to use the earthquake ability you unlock during the tutorial to kill them all and then use whatever rage you have left after that to spam whatever other ability the boss you're fighting is weak to. Of course, they have so much health that it'll still take several minutes, but you also have just as much, and they telegraph their attacks so much that it's impossible to die unless you walk away from the computer. The only time that pattern was not repeated before I stopped playing was in an area without a boss, and then it was just button mash to kill lots of enemies without a boss instead.

It's like they realized they'd made a game that was only 90 minutes long and kind of sucked (yes, other stuff sucks, like the lockon picking the wrong thing most of the time, the camera being a little flaky, every single animation in the air being totally wonky and waaaaaay too slow/floaty, including jumping and the earthquake attack you'll be constantly using, frightening amounts of lens flare/bloom...), so they added an extra zero to the end of the health of everything. There are absolutely much worse games out there, but there aren't a lot of games that feel more tedious.

If you really want to run around with no pants on, take your pants off right now. You have my permission. No matter where you are and no matter what happens, it'll be more fun than the game.

reviewText:
(This review was written after I beat the game on Normal difficulty)

There's wayyyy too many issues with this game, and they only became more and more prominent as the game went on.

First, the good: The game ran and controlled mostly fine. The only issue I had was the lock-on system. It was really difficult to position the cursor on what I wanted to attack, due to it bouncing all over the place, but outside of that, special moves and overall combat worked fine. The game mixes melee and ranged combat pretty seamlessly, the mouse buttons controlling what kind of attack you do. You can have four special attacks equipped at a time, and you can use them with Q, E, Z, and C. It's somewhat awkward at first, but I got used to it pretty fast.

That's about all the praise I can give it. The rest of it isn't great. You play as Ayumi, a treasure hunter, and she goes to find some legendary artifact. Turns out it's evil, and she accidentally becomes cursed. She has to remove her curse, while also stopping the Dark from overtaking everything. That's as deep as the story goes. There's no character development, there's nothing more. There's one extra character, and he's about as dull as you can be.

The game says it has levels. These 'levels' are usually nothing more than one room with a bunch of enemies. It feels more like an arena fighter than anything else. This doesn't start off too bad, enemies don't seem all that durable or numerous initially, but as the game goes on, these rooms become more and more tedious. Enemies will start having huge amounts of health, and only specific weaknesses to exploit. It's very possible to start taking 10-15 minutes in each room, trying to figure out the gimmick, or what it is you exactly need to kill.

As you defeat foes, you gather souls. These souls allow you to purchase upgrades at any time, from magical attacks to healing items. And...this removes any tension from combat. These healing items are pretty affordable, and also instant. Since you're in the menu while purchasing things, there's zero risk to this. As for abilities, as mentioned, you can only have four equipped at a time, and there's no hotkeys. You'll be having to switch these abilities in and out all the time, which means going back to the menu, binding the ability to a button, then resuming.

This is really annoying, especially since, after a certain point, every enemy has some sort of weakness to an element, and only that element. If you don't have an ability that uses a certain element that you need, you'll have to grind until you get it. Everything respawns every time you re-enter an area, although you don't have to fight them again, at least. Only if you need to.

The level layout is also another problem. As mentioned, all areas in the game are mostly rooms. Every time you clear a room, you receive an overview of your performance, and all the hidden items you found, like passive upgrades. This overview comes up...regardless if you fought anything or not, and you can't skip it. It only further slows down an already slow paced game.

Speaking of, the boss fights. They're all awful. They only have one specific weakness that you must exploit, and they have a TON of health. These fights go on for a very long time, regardless if you know the weakness or not. Again, these fights aren't really dangerous, since you can heal yourself on a whim, but they take forever. The game does give you hints on some of the bosses, but some others, you're on your own. There's one where they say, Use strong melee attacks to break his defense"

reviewText: I look at the reviews for X-Blades on the page and I honestly find myself baffled. Review after review recommending this game that I honestly wish I had never bought. In the interest of honesty, I will disclose that I only bought X-Blades at the request of a friend, with the promise of lunch at a hibachi steakhouse if I got the good ending. And as good as the steak and shrimp was, I'm not completely sure if it was worth it. I'll start with the story. What little story there is is so incredibly generic one could get the main gist with a few key words. Blah blah blah treasure. Blah blah blah Darkness. Blah blah blah ancient power. blah blah blah. This doesn't stop the main characters, though. I suppose just having a story is a major accomplishment for an entity as relatable as the half-eaten bag of crackers in my trash can. This is only half due to the inherent flatness of the characters though. The other half is because of the incompetence of the voice actors. Each and every line is delivered like the person standing behind the microphone has a gun to their head. The incredibly threatening recording sessions obviously having taken place weeks apart and in different locations. Then they just stitched the recordings together like someone trying to make a car by sewing construction paper together with string. The visual design is actually alright, feels like it's a bit behind the times. It would look fantastic on a PS2, but it falls short on modern consoles. The sound design is back and forth, as the music is good, but each individual sound effect feels like a tiny murder every time it plays. And finally, we come to gameplay, arguably the make-or-break point of game design. It's repetitive. It's incredibly repetitive. I honestly can't imagine why anybody outside of an insane asylum would play this game the entire way through without the promise of chicken and shrimp. If you aren't using the weightless melee attack, you're using a small pool of spells that you've picked out until the game decides that the enemy you're facing needs this specific type of spell. One particular boss requires you to use quite a few different spells, and you can only have so many equipped at once, so more than a few times during the fight, your main enemy will be the menu. In conclusion, Don't bother with X-Blades. if you absolutely can't help yourself, go find the soundtrack or something, but the game is absolutely not worth the time it takes to buy it.

The badness of this game is legend largely perpetuated by people who probably never played it.

It's a functional game with good mechanics, and performs well despite it being kind of old and ported during an era where ports were notorious for being nearly terrible across the board.

That's basically what this game is like, with a little bit of a cheesy story break every so often.

It shows up in bundles frequently for $1 or less.

I can't recommend the game in good faith, but if you can find it in a bundle, I don't think trying it out for a bit will cause you any harm.  You might like the game.  Opinions and all.

reviewText: I look at the reviews for X-Blades on the page and I honestly find myself baffled. Review after review recommending this game that I honestly wish I had never bought. In the interest of honesty, I will disclose that I only bought X-Blades at the request of a friend, with the promise of lunch at a hibachi steakhouse if I got the good ending. And as good as the steak and shrimp was, I'm not completely sure if it was worth it. I'll start with the story. What little story there is is so incredibly generic one could get the main gist with a few key words. Blah blah blah treasure. Blah blah blah Darkness. Blah blah blah ancient power. blah blah blah. This doesn't stop the main characters, though. I suppose just having a story is a major accomplishment for an entity as relatable as the half-eaten bag of crackers in my trash can. This is only half due to the inherent flatness of the characters though. The other half is because of the incompetence of the voice actors. Each and every line is delivered like the person standing behind the microphone has a gun to their head. The incredibly threatening recording sessions obviously having taken place weeks apart and in different locations. Then they just stitched the recordings together like someone trying to make a car by sewing construction paper together with string. The visual design is actually alright, feels like it's a bit behind the times. It would look fantastic on a PS2, but it falls short on modern consoles. The sound design is back and forth, as the music is good, but each individual sound effect feels like a tiny murder every time it plays. And finally, we come to gameplay, arguably the make-or-break point of game design. It's repetitive. It's incredibly repetitive. I honestly can't imagine why anybody outside of an insane asylum would play this game the entire way through without the promise of chicken and shrimp. If you aren't using the weightless melee attack, you're using a small pool of spells that you've picked out until the game decides that the enemy you're facing needs this specific type of spell. One particular boss requires you to use quite a few different spells, and you can only have so many equipped at once, so more than a few times during the fight, your main enemy will be the menu. In conclusion, Don't bother with X-Blades. if you absolutely can't help yourself, go find the soundtrack or something, but the game is absolutely not worth the time it takes to buy it.

reviewText:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CIn5U7KZrbY&list=UUnQL0hzRCQwxnRMV9Nn9i6g
X-Blades try to be spectacle fighter like Devil May Cry, God of War and so on, but it's far, far away from them. Here you don't have different weapons to choose or set of move. You relay on two swords and guns which are useless (after upgrading the guns they start to become somewhat useful) and a lot of mashing buttons.

After killing an enemy, you collect souls, which are the currency of the game, With them you can buy magic spells. You can equip four at any time. But they are almost the same!!! Lightning on sword, fire on sword, Earthquake or Fire Rage it doesn't matter.

From time to time you see new skill is unlocked, you open the menu to check it and where is it? You have buy some of the available spells and then you see what is unlocked. But what if i don't want to? Well there is no choice. The spells are tight with the bosses, not all but still. For example, there is this werewolf looking boss (which i fought 3 times) For 20 min or more i didn't hurt him once, then out of frustration i open you tube. You have to buy a specific skill named Sparkling Sword to beat him. How can I know that?! There is no indication that you need it. This is the same thing for some of the other bosses. And the fights with them are too long.

For activating spell you need Rage. This is why you use the swords, other than that as i wrote they are useless, so most of the time you count on spell with area of effect, like Fire Rage. Later in the game the skills are quite expensive, so prepare for grinding. The difference between area of effect spells are the animation for each one. They take you out of the action and after that the camera is in weird angle.

Games like this have some sort of move to avoid attacks. Here you can buy one, but it's not that useful and a lot of attacks become hard or impossible to avoid.

Graphics are good, but the cutscenes are bad, they look worse than the in-game graphics. Level design is boring, just ruins and they are basically arenas. To move to the next area you have to kill all enemies on screen.

The music is okay, rock and metal tracks, probably you won't remember it. Same thing can be said about the story. You play as Ayumi, treasure hunter and she touch something and she is cursed. It's completely forgettable.

I mentioned you don't have different set of moves. This isn't quite true. In the game you collect three types of artifacts. When you find enough, you gain more life or some moves for the swords or new skills for the guns (then they become somewhat useful). Let me buy them, I don't want look around just for upgrading my airstrike, which is useless!!!

I can go on and on with the negativity. There is some pleasure in the mindless action, but it won't last long. I didn't expect AAA game, but me some bad design decisions ruin the potential of X-Blades. It's not the worst game i've ever played It's often on sale if you have some interest, but don't even bother.

Pros: nice visuals, okay soundtrack, some mindless action, responsive controls

Cons: boring level design, no debt to the combat, repetitive, some skills/spells are directly tight with the bosses and it's not at least hinted what you need to buy for them, annoying heroine, forgettable story

reviewText:
I got this game for a dollar with a coupon.  It's hard to say no to a game for a dollar but normally it sells for a few dollars on steam.

The Good:  -  This game is not a bad ~concept~.   Cel shaded female anime character wielding two gun swords, who can shoot, slash, and cast spells you unlock with souls.  Character moves quickly like sonic the hedgehog, so think a quick moving sonic the hedgehog hack and slash that collects souls instead of rings... except the souls look like rings?  Not a terrible concept.  With pumped up metal music.
The Bad:     -  The graphics are not there.  This can be understandable in low budget first game. They are not downright terrible by any stretch of the imagination but with the high speed it makes me almost nauseus.  Feels like spawn rate is just too high / quick on monsters.
-  The cut scenes keep going choppy on my computer.
The Ugly:    - The way you assign the spells and buy the spells to the menu, the system is just kind of clunky and not easy on the eyes.   I think some improvements here with color scheme, easy UI, would really really help this game.
-  Why the music does this horrible garbled thing on my end I still fail to understand.  The music is generally fuzzy but it ups the level to a car radio in a tunnel during battles.
-   Tiny menu button in the corner when you press tab for spell buying is the only way to close the game.  Ctrl-Alt-Delete caused it to just become angry and make it's static loopy metal track go insane on my computer. Do yourself a favor and don't try to kill this program it's one of those that can't be killed and just gets more angry.

As it stands now I wouldn't recommend it, but unlike some games on steam I wouldn't outright say it's a bad concept either.  The concept of a high paced anime hack and slash is really a great idea.

reviewText:
I got this game for a dollar with a coupon.  It's hard to say no to a game for a dollar but normally it sells for a few dollars on steam.

The Good:  -  This game is not a bad ~concept~.   Cel shaded female anime character wielding two gun swords, who can shoot, slash, and cast spells you unlock with souls.  Character moves quickly like sonic the hedgehog, so think a quick moving sonic the hedgehog hack and slash that collects souls instead of rings... except the souls look like rings?  Not a terrible concept.  With pumped up metal music.
The Bad:     -  The graphics are not there.  This can be understandable in low budget first game. They are not downright terrible by any stretch of the imagination but with the high speed it makes me almost nauseus.  Feels like spawn rate is just too high / quick on monsters.
-  The cut scenes keep going choppy on my computer.
The Ugly:    - The way you assign the spells and buy the spells to the menu, the system is just kind of clunky and not easy on the eyes.   I think some improvements here with color scheme, easy UI, would really really help this game.
-  Why the music does this horrible garbled thing on my end I still fail to understand.  The music is generally fuzzy but it ups the level to a car radio in a tunnel during battles.
-   Tiny menu button in the corner when you press tab for spell buying is the only way to close the game.  Ctrl-Alt-Delete caused it to just become angry and make it's static loopy metal track go insane on my computer. Do yourself a favor and don't try to kill this program it's one of those that can't be killed and just gets more angry.

As it stands now I wouldn't recommend it, but unlike some games on steam I wouldn't outright say it's a bad concept either.  The concept of a high paced anime hack and slash is really a great idea.

reviewText:
It is a fantasy slasher consisting of connected arenas where you don't play typical levels but instead you fight boss-fights one after another.

Construction of game is weird because early it serves you most boring and unrewarding levels where it is only you and butt-crack of heroine [to wipe your tears away] and then gets better over time. Like it tries to scare away all but most patient ones instead of luring everyone with the best pieces at the beginning.

Levels: are monumental and well detailed, with great display of sunlight and shadows.

Enemies: are few but distinct and you will have to switch your attacks and spells/skills to defeat them. Later in the game enemies will appear in mixed groups so sometimes you will have to prioritize targets and apply different tools to different situations. Which is nice and i appreciate these moments a lot.
Even ingame bestiary is useful as you will learn from there about resistances of enemies.

Battles: with every level battles become more demanding, multiple stages of every boss fight, more resistances/vulnerabilities. Bad side is that there is too much repetition where you have to do the same action or series of actions over and over. But this is how boss fights were done over the years - i prefer to have endurance trial with bulletspoonge boss than QTE ;).
You can set your own difficulty level as game lets you heal during fight and it is only up to you if you use it - you have to pay for it with the same currency you buy upgrades, but it's some percent of your current wealth so you always can afford it.

pros:
+ gameplay [after early tutorial levels][yet during the game you will encounter another tutorial levels].
+ power-tripping - you are one-girl-army slashing through hundreds of enemies. Slaming ground to knock down enemies, fry tens of enemies with chainlightning, freeze everyone around you then shatter them with earthquake. Or enable transformation for speed boost and turn your pistols into machineguns. Just fave fun and enjoy the view.
+ great visual and audio effects.
+ cool soundtrack with vivid music for battles that calms down after last enemy falls so you can do sightseeing of beautiful levels with nice soundtrack in the background.
+ decent, but unfortunately scarce, platforming sections and bonus platforming for those who want to grab all collectibles.

cons:
- you can't play this game without being accused that you play it only to watch at the lower back of protagonist.
- poor early tutorial-levels. Probably were stuffed into the game day before release. Many people could become bored of it and fail to endure past it for the actual game.
- lack of some animations of enemies [like jumping or falling].
- anime characters doesn't suit the rest of the game artstyle [imo].
- no achievements for steam [not that i care but it's a steam release so lets play by the rules].
- story - dialogues, cutscenes, endings.

questionable pros/cons:
+/- only game, known to me, that require clothing mod because you have nude cheat enabled by default.

bottom line:
10e is a price of a pizza and a two beers to have with your friend, so if you have no friends then grab this game and have fun for few evenings :)

reviewText:
Think about God of War and everything that made it great aside from mashing a button to open up a chest.

Now take everything and make it slightly annoying; the result is more or less X-Blades. It's a semi-fun mindless buttonmasher with minor annoyances thrown in; certain enemies are so short it's hard to hit them with your blades, bullets and spells don't always go where you want them to, the plot is just shy of nonexistant, pots are somehow immune to your swords unless you get them at just the perfect angle, certain rooms have enemies that can only be defeated in a certain way but it's up to you to guess how, certain mechanics are explained long after it would've been nice to know about them, and there's no dedicated dodge button/stick. Your rage(mana) decays unless you're in combat or getting punched in the face, so you can run into situations where you have to choice but to let some monstrosity gnaw on you for a bit while you wait to get angry enough to use the only ability that will harm it.

While not good, it's not exactly bad. It's just a shame to see that it had potential yet missed the mark and dove off the cliff instead. Not really worth it at full price; I would not recommend purchasing it unless it's on sale.

Also, much bloom. Wear shades.

Beautiful, just beautiful.

reviewText:
It is a fantasy slasher consisting of connected arenas where you don't play typical levels but instead you fight boss-fights one after another.

Construction of game is weird because early it serves you most boring and unrewarding levels where it is only you and butt-crack of heroine [to wipe your tears away] and then gets better over time. Like it tries to scare away all but most patient ones instead of luring everyone with the best pieces at the beginning.

Levels: are monumental and well detailed, with great display of sunlight and shadows.

Enemies: are few but distinct and you will have to switch your attacks and spells/skills to defeat them. Later in the game enemies will appear in mixed groups so sometimes you will have to prioritize targets and apply different tools to different situations. Which is nice and i appreciate these moments a lot.
Even ingame bestiary is useful as you will learn from there about resistances of enemies.

Battles: with every level battles become more demanding, multiple stages of every boss fight, more resistances/vulnerabilities. Bad side is that there is too much repetition where you have to do the same action or series of actions over and over. But this is how boss fights were done over the years - i prefer to have endurance trial with bulletspoonge boss than QTE ;).
You can set your own difficulty level as game lets you heal during fight and it is only up to you if you use it - you have to pay for it with the same currency you buy upgrades, but it's some percent of your current wealth so you always can afford it.

pros:
+ gameplay [after early tutorial levels][yet during the game you will encounter another tutorial levels].
+ power-tripping - you are one-girl-army slashing through hundreds of enemies. Slaming ground to knock down enemies, fry tens of enemies with chainlightning, freeze everyone around you then shatter them with earthquake. Or enable transformation for speed boost and turn your pistols into machineguns. Just fave fun and enjoy the view.
+ great visual and audio effects.
+ cool soundtrack with vivid music for battles that calms down after last enemy falls so you can do sightseeing of beautiful levels with nice soundtrack in the background.
+ decent, but unfortunately scarce, platforming sections and bonus platforming for those who want to grab all collectibles.

cons:
- you can't play this game without being accused that you play it only to watch at the lower back of protagonist.
- poor early tutorial-levels. Probably were stuffed into the game day before release. Many people could become bored of it and fail to endure past it for the actual game.
- lack of some animations of enemies [like jumping or falling].
- anime characters doesn't suit the rest of the game artstyle [imo].
- no achievements for steam [not that i care but it's a steam release so lets play by the rules].
- story - dialogues, cutscenes, endings.

questionable pros/cons:
+/- only game, known to me, that require clothing mod because you have nude cheat enabled by default.

bottom line:
10e is a price of a pizza and a two beers to have with your friend, so if you have no friends then grab this game and have fun for few evenings :)
